questions.question: Factors determining slow circulation rate selection? (SELECT THREE)
questions.explanation: SCR must: minimize friction (B), allow kill mud mixing (C), not overwhelm gas separator (E). Surface burst and trip tank irrelevant to pump rate selection.

questions.question: Correct statements about SCR? (SELECT THREE)

options.D: SCR on DP gauge at remote panel

questions.explanation: Retake SCR when mud changes (C). Read on DP gauge at choke panel (D). Bit near bottom for true circulating pressure (E). SCR not through choke normally; not for formation pressure calc.

questions.question: SPM selection factors? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: Must stay within pump pressure limits (B) and not overwhelm surface equipment (E). DS/annulus volume affects stroke count, not rate.

questions.question: When to take/verify SCR? (SELECT TWO)

options.B: After well shut in on influx

questions.explanation: SCR each shift (A) ensures current value. After mud changes (D) because SCR varies with mud properties. After shut-in is too late; before casing is irrelevant.

questions.question: Why use slow pump rate during kick displacement?

options.B: Maintain high overbalance via annular losses

questions.explanation: Slower = less friction = less ECD = less formation stress. You can't prevent gas expansion (it WILL expand). Overbalance comes from mud weight, not APL during kill.

questions.question: Reasons for slow rate kick displacement? (SELECT FOUR)
questions.explanation: Slow rate: gives choke operator time (A), reduces pressures (C), allows surface handling (D), prevents MGS overload (F). Doesn't affect hydrate risk or migration speed.

questions.question: What increases pump pressure? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: Deeper well = more friction (B). Longer BHA = more restriction (D). Larger nozzles REDUCE pressure. Lighter mud REDUCES friction.

questions.question: SIDPP determined by? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: SIDPP = Formation pressure - DS hydrostatic. Depends only on formation pressure (D) and mud in DS (C). Influx characteristics affect SICP, not SIDPP.

questions.question: Which gauge indicates formation pressure?
questions.explanation: DP gauge reflects formation pressure through known mud column. Casing pressure affected by unknown influx. Accumulator is BOP hydraulic system.

questions.question: Float in string, how to read SIDPP?

options.A: Use SICP for kill mud calculation
options.C: Pump slowly until SICP increases; DP pressure is SIDPP
options.D: Pump at kill rate until SICP increases

questions.explanation: Float blocks DP from transmitting pressure. Pump slowly—when SICP starts to rise, you've overcome float resistance. DP reading at that moment = true SIDPP.

questions.question: Why is casing pressure higher than SIDPP?

options.A: Choke line larger than kill line
options.B: Influx usually lighter than mud weight
options.C: Choke line longer than kill line

questions.explanation: Influx (gas/oil/saltwater) is lighter than drilling mud. Less hydrostatic in annulus = more surface pressure needed to balance same formation pressure.

questions.question: Cuttings-loaded annulus effect on SICP?
questions.explanation: Cuttings are denser than mud. More cuttings = higher annular density = higher hydrostatic = LOWER surface pressure required.

questions.question: What determines pressure stabilisation time?
questions.explanation: Permeability = flow rate. High perm = fast fluid movement = quick stabilization. Porosity is storage; friction and migration are during circulation.

questions.question: Rig floor gauge reads lower than pump gauge. Why?

options.A: Pressure loss from pump to floor affects readings
options.B: Floor gauge lower than pump gauge

questions.explanation: Friction loss in surface lines between pump and floor reduces pressure. The further from pump, the lower the reading.

questions.question: SIDPP and SICP both rising by same amount. Cause?
questions.explanation: Gas migration increases pressure equally on both DS and annulus. Choke leak would affect SICP only. Second influx would show unequal changes.

questions.question: SICP primary use?
questions.explanation: SICP verifies proper startup—should match calculated ICP when coming to kill rate. Kill mud uses SIDPP. ICP calculation uses SIDPP + SCR.

questions.question: Gas migration, can't start pumps. How to maintain BHP?

options.A: Allow SIDPP +200 psi; bleed 200 psi via SICP
options.B: Allow SIDPP +200 psi; bleed 100 psi via SIDPP
options.C: Bleed DP in 100 psi increments at manifold
options.D: Bleed 1 bbl at time through choke

questions.explanation: Volumetric method: Allow pressure to build (work value, e.g., 200 psi), then bleed HALF through casing to maintain BHP constant. Bleed through choke, not DP.

questions.question: SIDPP 700, SICP 900, 13.5 ppg. After 30 min both increase 150 psi. Gas migration speed?
questions.explanation: 150 psi in 30 min = 150/(13.5 × 0.052) = 213.7 ft in 30 min = 427 ft/hr. Migration rate calculated from pressure rise and mud gradient.

questions.question: Pump speed reduced from 80 to 40 spm. New pressure? (Original 4000 psi)
questions.explanation: Pressure varies with square of rate. (40/80)² = 0.25. 4000 × 0.25 = 1000 psi

questions.question: 16,435 ft MD, 15.9 ppg mud, 12 bbl kick, DC capacity 0.0292 bbl/ft. Influx height?
questions.explanation: Influx height = Volume / Annular capacity = 12 / 0.0292 = 411 ft
